p: Although our models predict contrasting trends in the evolution of sprouting, we also note a similar life-history context to this trait in all three species. In particular, although sprouting exhibits a range of relationships with size and flowering status, growth exerts costs upon survival in all three species, at least in juvenile and vegetative plants ( figureÂ 2). These may be physiological or energetic costs of building above-ground structures, which use stored reserves beyond critical levels necessary for coping with difficult future conditions [ 28, 49]. This finding provides strong evidence that vegetative dormancy is an adaptive trait, rather than a bet-hedging trait, at least in these species.
